question: Where did the young woman live alone?
answer1: in the woods

question: Why was the young woman surprised every morning?
answer1: found fresh meat in the morning at her door

question: Who did the woman see gliding away into the forest?
answer1: a handsome young man

question: What happened after the woman saw the man?
answer1: The man became her husband and the woman had a son by him.

question: What did the woman tell the dog to do when the baby cried?
answer1: halloo for her

question: What happened after the woman came home?
answer1: She found her child gone and the dog too.

question: Where did the dog come from?
answer1: a distant country

question: Who had the dog and child been taken by?
answer1: an old woman from a distant country

question: What did the old women give the mother?
answer1: shoes that she might follow on

question: What did the mother have to do when she arrived at the next lodge?
answer1: set the toes of the moccasins they had given her pointing homeward

question: Who gave the mother the last instructions on how to proceed?
answer1: the friendly old grandmothers

question: What did the friendly old grandmothers tell the mother to do with a little bark dish?
answer1: fill it with the juice of the wild grape

question: What will happen after the woman fills the dish with the wild grape's juice?
answer1: the first child will come and find the woman out

question: Who was Spirit-Iron?
answer1: the dog

question: What did the drink do to Spirit-Iron?
answer1: taught him to see the truth of things as they were

question: What happened after Spirit-Iron drank the wild grape's juice?
answer1: sought out his young master

question: Why did the young woman throw out the meat?
answer1: She was bewitched by Mukakee Mindermoea.
answer2: The meat was so bitter and distasteful.

question: What did the young man tell the old Toad-Woman to do?
answer1: send some of the best of this meat to the stranger who has arrived lately

question: Who was the old Toad-Woman?
answer1: a child-thief

question: Where did the young man visit the stranger?
answer1: at her lodge of cedar-boughs

question: How did Spirit-Iron support the young man?
answer1: took the young man's arm
answer2: kept close by the young man's side
answer3: gave the young man many words of encouragement as they went along

question: How did the Toad-Woman know trouble was coming?
answer1: from something in the dog's eye

question: Why did the young man say the cradle the Toad-Woman brought him was not his cradle?
answer1: His cradle was of wampum.

question: According to the Toad-Woman, why did the young man look different from the rest of the children?
answer1: It was a very bright, clear blue sky when he was born.

question: What did the young man have to do to get free of the Toad-Woman?
answer1: kill a fat bear

question: Why did the Toad-Woman say that it was not very far to retrieve a fat bear?
answer1: A fat bear was the delight of the old Toad-Woman.

question: How did the young man kill the Toad-Woman's four children?
answer1: blew a strong breath in their faces

question: How did the Toad-Woman feel when she saw her children standing up by the door-posts with fat in their mouths?
answer1: astonished

question: What did the dog whisper to his master?
answer1: "Snakeberry!"

question: What happened after the young man called out for the snakeberry?
answer1: berries spread like scarlet all over the path, for a long distance

question: Why did the woman stoop down to pick and eat the berries?
answer1: She was almost as fond of these berries as she was of fat bears.

question: How did the Toad-Woman feel when she was trying to go forward?
answer1: anxious

question: How did the woman know the man brought her the meat?
answer1: She saw him even though she lived alone.
answer2: She saw him gliding away into the forest.

question: Why did Spirit-Iron look cautiously to see that no one was listening?
answer1: He did not want the old woman there to hear him.
answer2: He did not want the old woman to know he found the real mother.

question: Why did Spirit-Iron tell his young master that the old woman was not his mother?
answer1: Spirit-Iron found his real mother.
answer2: Spirit-Iron drank the juice of the wild grape.
answer3: Spirit-Iron wanted to reunite his young master with his real mother.

question: Why did the young man appear to doubt?
answer1: He did not know if the stranger was telling the truth.
answer2: He thought the Toad-Woman was his real mother.
answer3: He did not know who the stranger was.

question: How will the Toad-Woman feel when the young man begins to question her?
answer1: nervous

question: How did the young man know the stranger was telling the truth?
answer1: The Toad-Woman showed him his real cradle.
answer2: The cradle of the Toad-Woman was made of the same wampum the stranger gave him.
answer3: Spirit-Iron told him the Toad-Woman was not his real mother.

question: Why did the Toad-Woman think her children insulted the young man?
answer1: The children had fat in their mouths.
answer2: The children were hung up to mock the Toad-Woman.
answer3: The Toad-Woman did not know her children were dead yet.

question: Why did Spirit-Iron tell his master about the snakeberry?
answer1: Spirit-Iron knew the Toad-Woman could not resist the berries.
answer2: Spirit-Iron knew that the snakeberry vines would grow forever.
answer3: Spirit-Iron wanted to help the young man and his mother escape.
